I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Program Confirmation Mission in November 2004, the Government 
of Bhutan requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a project preparatory 
technical assistance (TA) to develop a program for the development of the financial sector 
including  nonbank  financial  institutions  (NBFIs).  The  request  was  congruent  with  the 
Government’s efforts to develop the country’s private sector through the provision of diversified 
financial services and better access to finance. The TA was included in ADB's Country Strategy 
and Program Update (CSPU) 2004–2006 for Bhutan.1  
2.  A fact-finding mission (the Mission) visited Thimphu, Bhutan on 14–22 February 2005. 
The Mission met with senior officials and technical staff from the Ministry of Finance (MOF), 
Department of Aid and Debt Management (DADM), Royal Monetary Authority (RMA), and other 
stakeholders including the Royal Insurance Corporation of Bhutan (RICB). The Government and 
the  Mission  reached  an  understanding  on  the  objectives,  scope,  financing  plan,  and 
implementation arrangements of the TA. The TA design and monitoring framework is shown in 
Appendix 1 and the initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Financial deepening has been taking place in Bhutan over the past 20 years as the 
broad money-to-gross domestic product (GDP) ratio increased from just 19.4% in 1985 to 44% 
by 2004. The expansion of the financial sector has occurred through both the growing size of 
their activities and the diversification of financial entities in the country. During the 1970s, the 
Bank of Bhutan (BOB) was the only financial institution, but since then, a number of entities 
have emerged including the Bhutan National Bank (BNB); two NBFIs, namely, RICB and Bhutan 
Development Finance Corporation (BDFC); and National Pension and Provident Fund (NPPF). 
Given the small size of the economy, hence limited absorptive capacity of the financial market, 
the number and level of operations of the financial institutions are perceived to be adequate at 
present. However, existing institutions need to be strengthened to improve their efficiency and 
widen  the  provision  of  innovative,  diversified,  and  quality  financial  services  in  their  core 
business. Also, it is essential to strengthen prudential regulation and supervision for better 
financial governance to ensure a conducive framework for further broadening and deepening of 
the financial sector. 
 
4.  RMA, established by the Royal Monetary Authority of Bhutan Act (1982), is mandated to 
act as the Government’s bank and advisor on matters relating to its functions. After over 20 
years of central banking development, RMA’s capacity and that of the financial sector have 
been gradually built up. Nonetheless, there is scope for further improvement particularly in 
regulation  and  enforcement  over  the  operations  of  the  financial  sector.  Currently,  RMA  is 
revising  the  RMA  Act  and  drafting  the  Financial  Services  Act  and  Insurance  Act3  for 
strengthening RMA’s position in regulating and supervising all existing financial institutions as 
well as in regulating insurance and securities.   
 
5.  RMA’s self-assessment and the financial sector review conducted under ADB TA 36874 
indicate a shortage of expertise and skills in the areas of (i) on-site and off-site supervision and

inspection of the insurance market, (ii) financial statement analysis, (iii) risk management and 
analysis, (iv) credit analysis, (v) banking supervision, and (vi) asset-liability management. As the 
banking and insurance businesses are growing at a remarkable speed and financial services 
such as automated teller machines (ATMs) and on-line banking are available, it is essential for 
RMA to enhance its skills for supervising financial institutions and for detecting any market 
manipulation  and  misconduct.  In  addition,  given  the  current  development  and  proposed 
changes in legislation and regulation necessitated by the expansion of the financial sector, it is 
critical  that  RMA  acquires  needed  legal  expertise  to  ensure  informed  review  of  drafted 
legislations and implementing regulations for the financial system. 
 
6.  During  the  Mission’s  discussions  with  RMA,  RICB  was  identified  as  one  of  the 
institutions that needed immediate attention. RICB was established by Royal Charter5 in 1975. 
Its insurance business covers life insurance, general insurance, group savings-cum-insurance, 
rural housing insurance and the provident fund. Until 2000, RICB had conducted extensive 
credit financing business due to the constant inflow of liquidity from pension and provident fund 
members. In 2000, the Government Employees Provident Fund was hived off from RICB.6 Since 
then, RICB has managed private provident funds for employees of private companies and used 
its large capital base to invest in real estate development. While RICB continues to be a 
monopoly in the insurance market and plays a vital role in the socioeconomic development of 
the country by facilitating finance and providing security, it needs to develop its skills in its 
investment function which differs from its core business for its large exposure in real estate 
investment  and  loan  receivables.  In  addition,  RMA  regulates  RICB  under  the  Financial 
Institutions Act (FIA). However, regulation and supervision under FIA is only limited to RICB’s 
investment activities. Relevant laws and regulations of insurance business operations are only 
being drafted under the Insurance Act and Financial Services Act. In view of the need to have 
consistency between the two Acts before enactment and to set up an urgently needed proper 
legal and regulatory framework to regulate, supervise, and monitor insurance operations, it is 
critical for RMA to receive legal support and skills training in insurance supervision. 
 
7.  Lessons  learned  and  recommendations  from  a  previous  ADB’s  financial  sector 
assistance7 suggested that due to recent increased competition from NBFIs and given the lack 
of appropriate investment opportunities, RICB has become a major lending company and the 
bulk of its income-earning assets are in the form of credit. If RICB is to restructure its profile as a 
traditional insurance company, it needs for training in risk management, actuarial valuation, 
information system, and in developing investment and market strategies to further strengthen 
institutional  and  technical  capacity.  The  issue  of  institutional  capacity  building  of  RICB  is 
imperative and has been underscored again by recent assessments,8 in view of ensuring proper 
insurance operations and its viability as a sound NBFI in the financial system.

8.  Another important issue of financial sector development that is intertwined with private 
sector development is lack of access to finance for entrepreneurs. ADB’s TA 36879 along with 
the  World  Bank  Private  Sector  Survey10  identified  the  constraints  and  issues  of  business 
borrowing and further indicated that developing the nonbank financial sector and providing 
innovative financial products and services, such as leasing and venture capital, can encourage 
greater competition of the financial system in the presence of the duopoly banking system, and 
thus improve finance access to enterprises,11 lower interest rates, and alleviate excess liquidity 
in  the  financial  system.  The  Royal  Securities  Exchange  of  Bhutan  (RSEB),  which  was 
established in 1993, has a fully automated trading system linked by a local area network to the 
trading floor. However, trading is relatively low so that RSEB trades only twice a week. As at 
end-December 2004, only 15 companies were listed on the exchange, with a total market 
capitalization of $78.5 million and a total turnover of $0.47 million. As the exchange is still in its 
infancy, RMA, acting as a securities commission, provides budget grants for the operations of 
RSEB.  One  of  the  issues  of  securities/capital  market  development  arises  as  the  central 
depository (CD) system, established to improve trading efficiency and settlement security, lacks 
a  proper  legal  framework  to  govern  it.  Only  about  25%  of  the  securities  outstanding  are 
deposited with the CD. It is foreseen that more trading and faster development in the exchange 
will  occur  once  adequate  regulations  are  in  place.  Further  strengthening  the  institutional 
capacity  of  RSEB  in  human  resources,  information  technology  (IT),  and  information 
management will also be needed for improved functioning of the securities/capital market.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The overall objective of the TA is to promote good governance, enhance financial sector 
capacity, and encourage competition by developing a more efficient nonbank financial sector. 
The TA will support (i) strengthening the banking supervision and insurance regulation functions 
of RMA, (ii) preparing the strategy for developing the financial sector/NBFIs, and (iii) building 
institutional capacity. In addition to institutional capacity building of RMA and other stakeholders 
including RICB, the main TA outcome is the design and implementation plans of the Financial 
Sector/NBFIs  Reform  Program  agreed  by  the  Government  and  ADB,  aiming  at  further 
developing the financial system, including the nonbank financial sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will comprise three main components.  
 
11.  Component  1:  Strengthening  Banking  Supervision  and  Insurance  Regulation 
Functions of RMA. The TA will support the following activities: (i) providing technical training, 
including on-the-job training, to the Financial Institutions Supervision Division of RMA and other 
relevant divisions within RMA in the areas of asset-liability management, financial statement 
analysis,  accounting  and  auditing  standards  and  practices,  and  banking  supervision  to 
strengthen RMA oversight over both bank and NBFIs; (ii) examining guidelines and regulations

in insurance operations and making recommendations for consistency with international best 
practices; and (iii) continuing the drafting of regulations for the Insurance Act and Financial 
Services Act, as needed, with a view to ensuring consistency of the two Acts before they are 
enacted. 
 
12.  Component  2:  Preparing  the  Strategy  for  Developing  the  Financial 
Sector/Nonbank Financial Institutions. The TA will prepare the overall design and principal 
implementation components of the Financial Sector/NBFIs Reform Program. The TA activities 
include (i) conducting a financial sector assessment including review of constraints and issues 
in  the  banking  sector,  securities/capital  market,  and  development  of  NBFIs;  reviewing  the 
existing legislative framework, acts, and regulations pertaining to the financial sector; giving 
additional focus on identifying the constraints on and measures for developing the nonbank 
financial institutions with a view to exploring the demand and possible scope for introducing 
innovative  financial  services  and  products;  also,  reviewing  the  present  operations  of  the 
domestic securities/capital market with focus on steps to promote good governance to ensure 
the proper functioning of the markets and exploring ways of encouraging greater and more 
broad-based market activity; (ii) from the findings of the financial sector assessment, developing 
a strategy for promoting financial products that may be justified, such as housing, leasing, and 
venture  capital  financing  in  Bhutan;  and  (iii)  devising  a  strategy  and  pinpointing  specific 
measures for promoting greater activity and interest in domestic securities/capital markets, 
including  improvements  in  supporting  infrastructure,  institutional  capacity,  and  market 
functioning.  
 
13.  Component  3:  Building  Institutional  Capacity.  The  TA  will  include  the  following 
activities: (i) providing technical training in areas of risk assessment and management, credit 
analysis,  and  actuarial  valuation  with  a  series  of  workshops;  (ii)  developing  appropriate 
investment  and  market  strategies  to  restructure  RICB’s  asset  base  for  improved  risk  and 
portfolio management; and (iii) identifying and developing a suitable management information 
system for RICB to improve operations and management. Workshop participants will include 
relevant technical staff from RMA and financial institutions. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $590,000 equivalent, comprising $467,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $123,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  finance  $500,000 
equivalent, which includes the entire foreign exchange cost and $33,000 equivalent in local 
currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program. The 
Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project. The Government will contribute the remaining $90,000 equivalent in kind as 
office space and facilities, counterpart staff, local transportation, and administrative and clerical 
support. ADB's financing will be used for (i) acquiring the services of international and domestic 
consultants, and (ii) organizing workshops and providing training as required to counterpart 
staff. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  DADM of MOF will be the Executing Agency for the TA. RMA will be the Implementing 
Agency. The TA will be implemented during a 10-month period starting in September 2005 and 
ending by July 2006. Counterpart staff will be nominated from RICB and RMA, and will work 
closely with TA consultants to ensure timely and effective TA implementation.

5
 
16.  ADB will engage seven international consultants for a total of 13 person-months and 
three domestic consultants for a total of 9 person-months to provide the required consulting 
services. Consulting services will be delivered intermittently over 10 months. An international 
consulting firm will be recruited using simplified technical proposals under the quality- and cost-
based selection method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting consultants. The consultant team (person-
months are in parentheses) will comprise a financial sector/banking supervision expert (team 
leader) (4), a securities/capital market expert (2), an insurance/NBFIs expert (3), an accounting 
and auditing expert (1), a legal expert on securities/capital markets (1), a legal expert on 
insurance/NBFIs (1), and an actuary (1). The domestic consultant team will include a financial 
sector specialist (4), a legal expert (2), and an IT specialist (3). The outline terms of reference 
are included in Appendix 4. 
 
17.  The  consultants  will  prepare  (i)  an  inception  report  within  15  days  of  their  fielding 
including a needs-based assessment and an action plan, (ii) a midterm report 4 months after 
fielding, i.e., by December 2005, (iii) a draft final report for the TA, to be submitted 3 weeks 
before the end of the consulting term, and (iv) a final report at the end of the consulting 
assignment. The midterm report will include a financial sector assessment to be used as the 
basis for formulating the strategy for further developing the financial sector over the medium and 
long  terms.  The  final  report  will  have  the  finalized  strategy  and  principal  implementation 
components of the Financial Sector/NBFIs Reform Program, and include all the necessary 
appendices required for the ADB report such as recommended policy changes (the policy 
matrix),  funding  agencies’  coordination  matrix,  poverty  impact  analysis,  and  environmental 
impact matrix of each proposed policy action.  
 
18.  At least two tripartite meetings among the principals of the TA will discuss the midterm 
and draft final reports. Broader and extensive consultations on policy issues will be emphasized 
to reach consensus on the program design with government officials and relevant stakeholders. 
All reports will be submitted (in hard and soft copies) to the Government and ADB for review 
and comments. Consultants will duly incorporate the comments received while finalizing the 
reports. The reports shall be made available 2 weeks from the date of the tripartite meetings or 
receipt of comments. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for preparing the Financial Sector/Nonbank Financial Institutions 
Reform Program, and hereby reports such action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan: 
 
Private sector development is vital in fostering economic growth and creating employment opportunities to 
achieve the development goals of the Ninth Five-Year Development Plan (2002–2007). However, as the private sector 
continues to face several constraints arising from the small-size domestic markets, lack of labor, underdeveloped 
infrastructure, and lack of adequate access to finance, the contribution of the private sector to overall gross domestic 
product (GDP) is yet to be the engine of economic growth or poverty reduction in Bhutan. Therefore, the Government 
of Bhutan recognized the need to develop the financial sector to support private sector growth. Lack of adequate 
finance and access to finance, coupled with high interest rates and high collateral requirements that are recognized as 
significant drawbacks for entrepreneurs will be addressed with the objective of recommending means to improve the 
financial system. At a broader level, the problem also seems due to the lack of competition among financial 
institutions, which in turn hinders the development of more and better financial products and services, such as leasing, 
venture capital, credit cards, and automated teller machines (ATMs). Hence, the technical assistance (TA) will also 
review and prepare a strategy to promote competition in the financial sector. 
 
The Project will support strengthening the financial system by promoting good governance in banking 
supervision  and  insurance  regulation,  building  institutional  capacity,  and  encouraging  financial  competition  by 
developing a more efficient nonbank financial sector. It is expected that better financial intermediation provided by an 
improved financial system including the nonbank financial sector can increase the ratio of credit to the private sector 
as percentage of total financial assets to more than the current 20% level and private sector contribution (in the 
manufacturing, trade and commerce, and services sectors) as percentage of GDP from the current 34% level. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Financial intermediation and market competition improve the efficiency of resource allocation and therefore 
enhance private sector competition and entrepreneurship. As a result, greater financial development generates more 
employment, induces better innovation, and augments high economic productivity to provide economy-wide benefits. 
The social benefits will be explored at an aggregate level. In addition, financial development underpins private sector 
development which is vital to the economic growth of Bhutan as expected in the Ninth Five-Year Plan. Higher private 
sector development is envisaged to absorb the 70,000 new labor market entrants, stimulate small- and medium-size 
enterprises (SMEs) growth, and improve country economic growth. The social and poverty impact will be appropriately 
analyzed with recommendations on specific financial services, products, and supervision and regulation for targeted 
financial sectors, institutions, and/or beneficiaries.  
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Roundtable discussions will be held with Ministry of Finance, Royal Monetary Authority, Royal Insurance 
Corporation of Bhutan, and other relevant stakeholders, including multilateral and bilateral organizations, to ensure 
participation of stakeholders in proposing quality action plans and recommendations.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
During TA implementation, there will be two or more workshops and training sessions. The workshops and 
training will secure good representation and participation of key players in the financial sector.

12  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
  1.  Financial Sector/Banking Supervision Expert (Team Leader) 
    (4 person-months) 
 
1.  The  expert  must  have  an  extensive  working  knowledge  of  the  operations  and 
supervision of the financial sector, both bank and nonbank. Knowledge of nonbank financial 
institutions (NBFIs) including insurance is also necessary because the team leader oversees the 
project implementation including strengthening regulations and building the capacity of the 
insurance industry. The consultant must be familiar with international best practices in the noted 
areas, with working experience in similar developing countries or small countries, particularly in 
South Asia. Working experience in a financial authority type of regulatory systems would be 
desirable. It would be an advantage if the expert could demonstrate good understanding of the 
history and culture of the Bhutanese financial market and the current situation of the country’s 
legal and regulatory system. The consultant should possess good information-sharing skills in 
conducting  workshops,  on-the-job  training,  communicating  with  the  counterpart  and  team 
members, and preparing reports satisfactory to counterparts and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). The consultant will work closely with the rest of the team in their respective areas of the 
terms of reference (TOR). The tasks and responsibilities of the expert will include  
 
(i)  developing a system for the Financial Institutions Supervision Division (FISD) of 
Royal  Monetary  Authority  (RMA)  that  ensures  a  satisfactory  level  of  bank 
transparency  by  monitoring  major  parameters  including  (a)  financial 
performance, (b) financial position, (c) risk management strategies and practices, 
(d) risk exposure, (e) accounting policies, and (f) basic business, management 
and corporate governance information; 
(ii)  in close coordination with other team members, conducting training workshops 
including on-the-job training to FISD and other relevant staff within RMA in areas 
of asset-liability management, financial statement analysis, credit analysis, risk 
assessment and management, and, as necessary, other possible areas related 
to efficient risk assessment and fund management. Trainees can include staff 
from  Royal  Insurance  Corporation  of  Bhutan  (RICB),  National  Pension  and 
Provident Fund (NPPF), Bhutan Development Finance Corporation (BDFC), and 
other relevant agencies/institutions;  
(iii)  with inputs from relevant experts in the consulting team, conducting a financial 
sector assessment (i.e., the midterm report) including review of constraints and 
issues  of  the  banking  sector,  securities/capital  market,  and  NBFIs  and  the 
governance  structure;  reviewing  the  existing  legislative  framework,  acts,  and 
regulations  pertaining  to  the  financial  sector;  preparing  the  financial  sector 
assessment with additional focus on identifying constraints on and measures for 
developing the nonbank financial institution including exploring the demand and 
possible scope for introducing innovative financial services and products; and 
reviewing the present operations of the domestic securities/capital market to 
define the scope for further developing it; 
(iv)  coordinating with the rest of the team to prepare the overall design and principal 
implementation  components  of  the  Financial  Sector/NBFIs  Reform  Program,

Appendix 4  13 
 
which includes developing strategies for promoting financial products such as 
housing, leasing, and venture capital financing in Bhutan; and 
(v)  advising on overall consulting team work and activities, and in close coordination 
with team members conducting roundtable discussions with the Government and 
relevant stakeholders to collect information and disseminate final findings. 
  2.  Securities/Capital Market Expert (2 person-months) 
2.  The  expert  must  have  an  extensive  working  knowledge  of  the  operations  and 
supervision  of  securities/capital  markets.  He/she  should  be  familiar  with  international  best 
practices  and  have  working  experience  in  similar  developing  countries  or  small  countries, 
particularly in South Asia. It would be an advantage if the expert could demonstrate good 
understanding of the history and culture of the Bhutanese securities/capital market. The tasks 
and responsibilities will include  
 
(i)  working closely with the team leader to prepare the financial sector assessment 
to review the constraints and issues of securities/capital market development 
including  examining  the  existing  legislative  framework,  acts,  and  regulations 
pertaining to securities/capital market development. The securities/capital market 
assessment  should  review  the  present  operations  of  the  domestic 
securities/capital  market  and  pinpoint  the  issues  involved  in  operating  the 
securities exchange, expanding the dealer/broker network and investor market, 
and updating current Information Technology (IT) and Management Information 
System  (MIS).  Identify  measures  for  further  improving  the  securities/capital 
market; 
(ii)  defining the scope and drafting a strategy for strengthening the securities/capital 
market of Bhutan, with measures to improve on its supporting infrastructure, 
institutional capacity, and market functioning where recommended. In particular, 
the  securities/capital  market  expert  will  work  closely  with  the  domestic  IT 
specialist in recommending operational changes needed to the existing IT and 
MIS of Royal Securities Exchange of Bhutan (RSEB) to improve its efficiency and 
functioning.  These  should  also  cover,  but  will  not  limited  to,  setting  up  an 
information  disclosure  system  and  developing  a  securities  database  and 
information processing system; and 
(iii)  ensuring the consistency of legislation and regulations (e.g., Companies Act 
2000 and draft Financial Services Act) pertaining to securities exchange and 
proposed legislation for a central depository (CD) system, with the support of the 
legal  expert  on  securities/capital  markets,  and  recommend  changes  where 
necessary.  
  3.  Insurance/Nonbank Financial Institutions (NBFIs) Expert (3 person-months) 
3.  The  expert  must  have  extensive  working  knowledge  of  prudential  regulation  and 
supervision of the insurance industry, particularly on-site examination and off-site supervision as 
well as knowledge of international best practices. In addition, he/she should have practical 
experience in developing NBFIs, such as insurance companies, leasing, housing, and venture 
capital in developing countries. Demonstrated good understanding of the history and culture of 
the nonbank financial market in Bhutan or other similar developing countries especially in Asia 
would be desirable. The tasks and responsibilities of the expert will include

14  Appendix 4 
 
(i)  reviewing the existing financial reports of RICB, including off-site reviewing, such 
as visit to the head office in Phuentsholing and a few branches of RICB to 
examine current insurance operations; 
(ii)  developing  an  appropriate  investment  and  market  strategy  for  RICB  to 
restructure its assets based on improved risk and portfolio management with 
support of the international actuary; and, with support of the domestic IT expert, 
identifying and developing a suitable MIS for RICB to improve operations and 
management; 
(iii)  in coordination with the legal expert on insurance/NBFIs, drafting the Insurance 
Act or other relevant regulations and formulating clearly defined policy objectives 
for prudential insurance supervision and guidelines, including a comprehensive 
framework of well-defined performance indicators such as reserve requirements 
and a performance evaluation system;  
(iv)  in coordination with the international accounting and auditing expert, reviewing 
the  existing  accounting  and  auditing  system  and  practices  in  the  insurance 
industry  and  recommending  changes  where  necessary;  developing  a  written 
examination manual or checklists for both on-site and off-site supervision of the 
insurance industry; and training supervisors of FISD in insurance examination 
techniques and skills, combing on-the-job training and classroom instructions; 
(v)  identifying the constraints on and measures for developing NBFIs and exploring 
the demand and possible scope for introducing innovative financial services and 
products  such  as  leasing,  housing,  venture  capital  in  Bhutan;  and  providing 
relevant inputs for preparing the financial sector assessment; 
(vi)  from the findings of the financial sector assessment, developing a strategy for 
promoting  financial  products  such  as  housing,  leasing,  and  venture  capital 
financing in Bhutan; and 
(vii)  in close coordination with the legal expert on insurance/NBFIs, identifying laws 
and regulations to be strengthened or amended to promote nonbank financial 
sector development; and further providing recommended and drafted changes in 
the pertinent acts or laws, and drafting new legislations, as necessary. 
  4.  Accounting and Auditing Expert (1 person-month) 
4.  The consultant should be a certified public account (CPA) or has equivalent certification 
and extensive practical experience in international standards and practices of accounting and 
auditing policies for the financial sector. Demonstrated good understanding of the accounting 
and  auditing  system,  practices  and  procedures  in  Bhutan  or  other  developing  countries 
especially in South Asia will be desirable. Specific responsibilities will include  
(i)  working together with RMA, RICB, and other relevant stakeholders in reviewing 
the existing accounting and auditing system and practices and identifying specific 
provisions  of  local  standards  that  depart  from  international  standards;  and 
drafting amendments to existing accounting and auditing standards to conform 
with international standards, as applicable, and ensure conformity with local laws;

Appendix 4  15 
 
(ii)  coordinating with the team leader in providing on-the-job training to RMA staff in 
areas of accounting and auditing standards and financial statement analysis of 
financial institutions for compliance with RMA disclosure rules and regulations; 
and 
(iii)  in coordination with the insurance/NBFIs expert, developing accounting, auditing, 
and  reporting  requirements  for  RMA  that  will  enhance  the  transparency  of 
insurance information and operations to improve RMA’s oversight. 
  5.  Legal Expert on Securities/Capital Markets (1 person-month) 
5.  The expert should be a lawyer, conducting desk review and providing legal advice to the 
securities/capital  market  expert,  to  strengthen  and  amend  laws  and  regulations  in  his/her 
respective areas of responsibility. The expert must have extensive working knowledge of the 
legal  and  regulatory  framework  of  capital  markets  particularly  in  small  countries  or  similar 
developing countries in Asia and good knowledge of international best practices. Demonstrated 
good  understanding  of  the  current  legal  and  regulatory  framework  in  Bhutan  will  be  an 
advantage.  The  expert  will  be  reviewing  and  examining  the  existing  legal  and  regulatory 
framework for the securities/capital market; revising, as necessary, the rules and regulations 
relevant to the securities exchange (e.g., Companies Act 2000 and draft Financial Services Act) 
with a view to ensuring the consistency of legislation; and providing drafted amendments where 
necessary. 
  6.  Legal Expert on Insurance/Nonbank Financial Institutions (1 person-month)  
6.  The legal expert will be a lawyer, specializing in insurance. He/she will conduct desk 
review and provide legal advice to the insurance/NFIs expert to strengthen and amend laws and 
regulations  in  his/her  respective  responsibilities.  He  or  she  must  have  extensive  working 
knowledge of the legal and regulatory framework of the insurance industry, leasing, housing, 
and venture capital as well as knowledge of international best practices in small countries or 
other similar developing countries in Asia. Demonstrated good understanding of the history and 
culture of the nonblank financial sector and the current legal and regulatory framework in 
Bhutan will be an advantage. He/she will undertake 
 
(i)  reviewing and continuing the drafting of regulations for the draft Insurance Act 
and Financial Services Act, and ensuring the consistency between the two Acts; 
and  reviewing  other  relevant  laws  and  regulations  relevant  to  the  insurance 
industry, and drafting recommended laws or acts, as necessary; and 
 
(ii)  reviewing  and  examining  the  existing  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for 
introducing recommended innovative financial products, such as housing finance, 
leasing, and venture capital finance, in Bhutan; and recommending changes in 
rules and regulations for promoting the nonbank financial sector as necessary. 
  7.  Actuary (1 person-month) 
7.  The international actuary will be a licensed actuarial specialist with extensive working 
knowledge of the insurance industry including its regulatory procedures, reporting requirements, 
and international best-practice policies. A good understanding of and relevant exposure to the 
insurance sectors in emerging markets, preferably in developing countries similar to Bhutan, will 
be desirable. The actuary in coordination with the insurance/NBFIs expert, will obtain detailed 
information of the insurance plan rules and advising on suitable assumptions to be used in

16  Appendix 4 
actuarial valuation; analyzing the actuarial approaches adopted by RICB; and developing an 
appropriate actuarial valuation method for RICB.  
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
  1.  Financial Sector Specialist (4 person-months)  
8.  The specialist will have a background in financial sector development. He/she should 
have a good understanding of the Bhutanese financial market development and the country’s 
current legal and regulatory system in the financial sector; must be proficient in English; and 
preferably, have experience in working with international consultants and the Government. The 
specific responsibilities will include  
 
(i)  assisting the team leader in all aspects of his/her tasks within the TOR; and  
(ii)  under the guidance of the team leader and in coordination with the international 
experts,  collecting  and  analyzing  financial  information  and  data,  and  making 
them available in English and in an organized and clear format; and preparing 
materials  for  workshops  and  roundtable  discussions  including  translation  of 
documents and interpretation in workshops/roundtable discussions. 
  2.  Legal Expert (2 person-months)  
9.  The expert will have a solid background in law and good understanding of the country’s 
current legal and regulatory system in the financial sector and proficient in English. Preferably, 
he/she should have experience in working with international consultants and the Government. 
The consultant will undertake the following tasks  
(i)  assisting the international legal experts in all aspects of the tasks within their 
TORs; and 
(ii)  assisting the team leader and other relevant international experts in collecting 
and  reviewing  required  legal  documents  and  information,  and  making  them 
available  in  English  and  in  an  organized  and  clear  format;  and  preparing 
materials for workshops and roundtable discussions including translation of legal 
documents and interpretation in workshops/roundtable discussions. 
  3.  IT Specialist (3 person-months) 
10.  The consultant should have a degree in computer science and experience with MIS. The 
consultant will support the securities/capital market expert in upgrading a suitable IT system and 
MIS for RSEB to improve securities exchange in the securities/capital market and provide 
training  support  to  relevant  stakeholders  as  necessary.  The  specialist  will  also  assist  the 
insurance/NBFIs expert in developing, operationalizing, and managing the MIS for RICB within 
his/her terms of reference.
